 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>1. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (continued) </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Airlines, </I>and Accounting Principles Board (&#147;APB&#148;) Opinion No.&nbsp;28, &#147;Interim Financial Reporting&#148;. This FSP prohibits the use
of the accrue-in-advance method of accounting for planned major maintenance activities in annual and interim financial reporting periods. The guidance in this FSP shall be applied to the first fiscal year beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2006. The
Company intends to adopt this standard for the fiscal year beginning January&nbsp;1, 2007. The Company is currently evaluating what impact, if any, this amendment will have on its financial statements, including the potential impact to retrospective
periods. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Reclassification</I><I></I>&#151;Certain reclassifications have been made to prior year balances to conform to current year
presentations. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>2. Discontinuance of Operations and Asset Disposal </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Strategic Decisions </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As part of the Company&#146;s ongoing strategic evaluation of operations, the
following businesses have been discontinued: Nigeria, Venezuela, and the TXP-4 Plant, collectively the &#147;Discontinued Operations&#148;, and accordingly, these businesses are presented as discontinued operations in the preceding consolidated
financial statements. The net assets and net liabilities related to the Discontinued Operations are shown on the Consolidated Balance Sheets as &#147;Assets of discontinued operations&#148; and &#147;Liabilities of discontinued operations&#148;,
respectively. The results of the Discontinued Operations are shown on the Consolidated Statements of Operations as &#147;Loss from discontinued operations net of provision for income taxes&#148; for all periods shown. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The separate results of the Discontinued Operations, as well as a breakdown of the major classes of assets and liabilities included as part of
Discontinued Operations, are detailed in the subsequent tables. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Nigeria </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On February&nbsp;7, 2007, the Company sold its Nigeria operations through a share purchase agreement for total consideration of $155,250. In conjunction
with this transaction, the Company bought out certain minority interests at a total cost of $10,500. See Note 17&#151;Subsequent Events for more information on the sale. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Nigeria operations and assets were previously included in the Company&#146;s <I>International</I> segment and retrospectively presented as discontinued operations on the Company&#146;s Form 8-K filed December&nbsp;8,
2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As part of the sales process, the Company continues to evaluate the carrying value of the Nigeria assets and operations with respect
to their estimated market value. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company did not recognize an impairment of the Nigeria assets based upon this analysis. Any impairment would be included in the &#147;Loss from discontinued operations net of
provision for income taxes&#148;. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Pipe coating joint venture </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Kanssen International Pipe Coating Services Limited (&#147;Kanssen&#148;) and Willbros West Africa, Inc. (&#147;WWAI&#148;) a subsidiary of the Company entered into an agreement to upgrade facilities at the WWAI Choba
pipe coating facility. The agreement was signed in June 2006 and included an installation of new concrete weight coating equipment furnished by Kanssen. WWAI and Kanssen participate in the venture with a 50 percent interest for each party with WWAI
being paid a management fee on each contract not to exceed 9 percent of the </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">72 </FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>WILLBROS GROUP, INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(In thousands,
except share and per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>2. Discontinuance of Operations and Asset Disposal (continued) </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">contract revenue. Currently, the pipe coating transactions are included in the revenues and expenses of the related WWAI projects. In 2006, the pipe coating
facility had approximately $16.5 million in contract revenue. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Venezuela </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Asset disposal&#151;On August&nbsp;17, 2006, the Company entered into a share purchase agreement with a Venezuelan company (the &#147;Venezuelan
Buyer&#148;), pursuant to which the Company sold all of its membership interests in Willbros (Barbados) Limited, Inc. (&#147;WBL&#148;), a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company. WBL owns all of the assets and operations of the Company in Venezuela,
with the exception of joint-venture interest in Harwat International Finance Corporation NV (&#147;Harwat&#148;). The Company received cash payments of $7,000 for conveyance of WBL with no gain recognized subject to the pending sale discussed below.
The Venezuela operations and assets were previously a component of the Company&#146;s <I>International</I> segment and are retrospectively presented as discontinued operations in the Company&#146;s Form 8-K filed December&nbsp;8, 2006. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Joint-venture interest disposal&#151;As part of the share purchase agreement, the Venezuelan Buyer agreed to purchase the Company&#146;s 10 percent
interest in Harwat, as well as assume all guarantees of the Company related to the 10 percent interest in Harwat. The sale of the Harwat interest was completed November&nbsp;28, 2006. The Company received a commitment from the Venezuelan Buyer to
pay $3,300 before December&nbsp;4, 2013. The present value of this commitment is $1,775. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company estimates no gain or loss on the sale
of WBL and its 10 percent interest in Harwat. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">TXP-4 Plant </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Asset disposal&#151;On January&nbsp;12, 2006, the Company entered into a purchase agreement and release with Williams Field Services Company (&#147;Williams&#148;), a wholly-owned subsidiary of The Williams Companies,
Inc., pursuant to which the Company sold to Williams all of its membership interest in Opal TXP-4 Company, LLC, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company (the &#147;LLC&#148;). The LLC owns a gas processing plant known as the TXP-4 Plant (the
&#147;TXP-4 Plant&#148;) at Opal in Lincoln County, Wyoming, in addition to certain facilities, equipment and supplies related to the TXP-4 Plant. Prior to the sale, the TXP-4 Plant was a component of the <I>US&nbsp;&amp; Canada</I> segment and is
retrospectively presented as discontinued operations on the Company&#146;s Form 8-K filed December&nbsp;8, 2006. The Company received cash payments of $27,944 for conveyance of the LLC and realized a gain of $1,342, net of taxes of $691, reflected
as a component of the &#147;Loss from discontinued operations net of provision for income taxes&#148;. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition to the cash payments
described above, Williams agreed to pay the Company a portion of any recovery that Williams may obtain based on damages, loss or injury related to the TXP-4 Plant up to $3,400. This settlement is contingent upon Williams&#146; recovery from various
third parties and is the only ongoing potential source of cash flows subsequent to the Purchase Agreement date. The timing and amount of any resolution to these claims cannot be estimated. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">73 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

<h5 align="left"><a href="#INDEX">Index to Financial Statements</a></h5>

ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(In thousands,
except share and per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

<h5 align="left"><a href="#INDEX">Index to Financial Statements</a></h5>


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>WILLBROS GROUP, INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(In thousands,
except share and per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>2. Discontinuance of Operations and Asset Disposal (continued) </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Nigeria Income Taxes </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In Nigeria, the Company is subject to a deemed profit tax, which creates tax provisions based on gross revenue rather than pre-tax income. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Nigeria Federal Tax Audit </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company&#146;s operations in Nigeria have been under audit by the
Federal Inland Revenue Service (&#147;FIRS&#148;) for taxable years 1998 through 2004. The primary issues being investigated are related to transfer the pricing and unsubstantiated expenses. At this time, the Company estimates a possible additional
tax liability in the range of $1,200 to $5,000. Based on current financial information, there is no better estimate of tax liability associated with the FIRS audit. Because there is no better estimate at this time, and because the Company does not
expect to resolve this audit within one year, the Company has recorded a deferred income tax liability of $1,200. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Nigeria National Labor Contract
</I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The previous Nigerian national labor contract, covering approximately 1,600 national laborers at the Company&#146;s Choba Site 1
facility expired in March 2006. A replacement agreement executed in May 2006 mistakenly included labor rate increases ranging between 300 percent to 350 percent which the labor union claims are binding upon the Company notwithstanding the obvious
mistake in fact and other legal deficiencies in the form and substance of the replacement agreement (&#147;the May Agreement&#148;). However, based upon opinions of legal counsel in Nigeria, for a variety of reasons the Company believes the May
Agreement is unenforceable in its current form and the Company and its legal counsel are pursuing measures to rectify the mistake and related deficiencies in the purported agreement, including, without limitation, through negotiation, mediation, and
judicial actions provided for under the labor laws of Nigeria. During this rectification process, however, the Company has voluntarily increased the labor rate by 20 percent. An accrued liability of $5,514 has been recorded at December&nbsp;31, 2006
to reflect the Company&#146;s current estimate of additional end-of-service costs attributable to reaching a mutually acceptable final form of labor agreement. Although the Company does not currently anticipate that the May Agreement will be
determined to be enforceable in its current mistaken form, should rectification of that agreement be unsuccessful through the labor relations and related legal processes now underway, a substantially greater monthly labor expense would be incurred
by the Company and an estimated additional $26,000 of end-of-service liability would result. Also, this rectification process now underway by the Company has incited protests and strikes from the rank and file workers covered by the May Agreement.
The labor union has complained to national, local and regional politicians and the matter will be heard by the Labor Board to be resolved. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">75 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>2. Discontinuance of Operations and Asset Disposal (continued) </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Cash </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Discontinued Operations in Nigeria had $36,683 of restricted cash at December&nbsp;31, 2006. This amount was in a consortium bank account that requires the approval of the Company and its consortium partner to disburse funds. Additionally,
cash and cash equivalents for Nigeria contained $9,482 that was designated to specific project uses. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Inventory </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Discontinued Operations in Nigeria had parts and supplies inventories of $21,645 and $16,818 net of reserves of $12,159 and $5,052 at December&nbsp;31,
2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, respectively. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Loss provision on contracts </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company has recognized $33,957 of estimated losses related to two projects in Nigeria as of December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Contingencies, Commitments and Other Circumstances </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2006, other assets and accounts receivable of the Discontinued Operations include anticipated recoveries from insurance or third parties of $1,191 primarily related to the repair of pipelines. The Company believes the
recovery of these costs from insurance or other parties is probable. Actual recoveries may vary from these estimates. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">At December&nbsp;31,
2006, the Company had approximately $22,625 of letters of credit outstanding associated with the Discontinued Operations representing the maximum amount of future payments the Company could be required to make. See Note 13&#151;Contingencies,
Commitments and Other Circumstances for additional information on letters of credit and insurance bonds. The Company had no liability recorded as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, related to these commitments. </FONT></P> <P

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>WILLBROS GROUP, INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(In thousands,
except share and per share amounts) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>4. Contracts in Progress </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Contract costs and recognized income not yet billed on uncompleted contracts arise when revenues have been recorded but the amounts cannot be billed under the terms of the contracts. Such amounts are recoverable from
customers upon various measures of performance, including achievement of certain milestones, completion of specified units or completion of the contract. Also included in contract cost and recognized income not yet billed on uncompleted contracts
are amounts the Company seeks to collect from customers for change orders approved in scope but not for price associated with that scope change (unapproved change orders). Revenue for these amounts are recorded equal to cost incurred when
realization of price approval is probable and the estimated amount is equal to or greater than the Company&#146;s cost related to the unapproved change order. Unapproved change orders involve the use of estimates, and it is reasonably possible that
revisions to the estimated recoverable amounts of recorded unapproved change orders may be made in the near-term. If the Company does not successfully resolve these matters, a net expense (recorded as a reduction in revenues), may be required, in
addition to amounts that have been previously provided for. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Contract cost and recognized income not yet billed and related amounts billed
as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 were as follows: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>2006 Credit Facility </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On October&nbsp;27, 2006, Willbros USA, Inc., a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company, entered into a new $100,000 three-year senior secured synthetic credit facility (the &#147;2006 Credit Facility&#148;) with a
group of lenders led by Calyon New York Branch (&#147;Calyon&#148;). The 2006 Credit Facility replaces the Company&#146;s 2004 Credit Facility. The Company may elect to increase the total capacity under the 2006 Credit Facility to $150,000, with
consent from Calyon. The Company currently has a commitment from Calyon, which expires August 7, 2007 to underwrite an increase to the 2006 Credit Facility by $25,000 subject to certain terms and conditions. The </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">79 </FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>WILLBROS GROUP, INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(In thousands,
except share and per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>7. Long-term Debt (continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Company will increase the 2006 Credit Facility only if it has requirements to issue letters of credit in excess of $100,000. The 2006 Credit Facility may be
used for standby and commercial letters of credit, borrowings or a combination thereof. Borrowings, which may be made up to $25,000 less the amount of any letter of credit advances or financial letters of credit, must be repaid at least once a year
and no new revolving advances made for a period of 10 consecutive business days thereafter. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Fees payable under the 2006 Credit Facility
include a facility fee at a rate per annum equal to 5.0 percent of the 2006 Credit Facility capacity, payable quarterly in arrears (the facility fee will be reduced to 2.75 percent if the Company obtains a rating from S&amp;P and Moody&#146;s
greater than B and B2, respectively), and a letter of credit fee equal to 0.125 percent per annum of aggregate commitments. Interest on any borrowings is payable quarterly in arrears at the adjusted base rate minus 1.00 percent or at a Eurodollar
rate at the Company&#146;s option. The 2006 Credit Facility is collateralized by substantially all of the Company&#146;s assets, including stock of the Company&#146;s principal subsidiaries. The 2006 Credit Facility contains a requirement for the
maintenance of a $10,000 minimum cash balance, prohibits the payment of cash dividends and includes customary affirmative and negative covenants, such as limitations on the creation of certain new indebtedness and liens, restrictions on certain
transactions and payments and maintenance of a maximum senior leverage ratio, a minimum fixed charge coverage ratio and minimum tangible net worth requirement. A default may be triggered by events such as a failure to comply with financial covenants
or other covenants, a failure to make payments when due, a failure to make payments when due in respect of or a failure to perform obligations relating to debt obligations in excess of $5,000, a change of control of the Company or certain insolvency
proceedings as defined by the 2006 Credit Facility. The 2006 Credit Facility is guaranteed by the Company and certain other subsidiaries. Unamortized costs associated with the creation of the 2006 Credit Facility total $1,986 and are included in
other assets at December&nbsp;31, 2006. These costs are being amortized to general and administrative expense over the three-year term of the credit facility ending October 2009. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, there were no borrowings outstanding under the 2006 Credit Facility and there were $64,545 in outstanding letters of
credit, consisting of $41,920 issued for projects in continuing operations and $22,625 issued for projects related to discontinued operations. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I>6.5%
Senior Convertible Notes </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On December&nbsp;22, 2005, the Company entered into a purchase agreement (the &#147;Purchase
Agreement&#148;) for a private placement of $65,000 aggregate principal amount of its 6.5% Senior Convertible Notes due 2012 (the &#147;6.5% Notes&#148;). The private placement closed on December&nbsp;23, 2005. During the first quarter of 2006, the
initial purchasers of the 6.5% Notes exercised their options to purchase an additional $19,500 aggregate principal amount of the 6.5% Notes. Collectively, the primary offering and the purchase option of the 6.5% Notes total $84,500. The net proceeds
of the offering were used to retire existing indebtedness and provide additional liquidity to support working capital needs. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The 6.5%
Notes are governed by an indenture dated December&nbsp;23, 2005 and were entered into by and among the Company, as issuer, Willbros USA, Inc., as guarantor (&#147;WUSAI&#148;), and The Bank of New York, as Trustee (the &#147;Indenture&#148;), and
were issued under the Purchase Agreement by and among the Company and the initial purchasers of the 6.5% Notes (the &#147;Purchasers&#148;), in a transaction exempt from the registration requirements of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended (the
&#147;Securities Act&#148;). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Pursuant to the Purchase Agreement, the Company and WUSAI have agreed to indemnify the Purchasers, their
affiliates and agents, against certain liabilities, including liabilities under the Securities Act. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">80 </FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>WILLBROS GROUP, INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(In thousands,
except share and per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>7. Long-term Debt (continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The 6.5% Notes are convertible into shares of the Company&#146;s common stock at a conversion rate of
56.9606 shares of common stock per $1,000.00 principal amount of notes (representing a conversion price of approximately $17.56 per share resulting in 4,813,171 shares at December&nbsp;31, 2006), subject to adjustment in certain circumstances. The
6.5% Notes are general senior unsecured obligations. Interest is to be paid semi-annually on June&nbsp;15 and December&nbsp;15, beginning June&nbsp;15, 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The 6.5% Notes mature on December&nbsp;15, 2012 unless the notes are repurchased or converted earlier. The Company does not have the right to redeem the 6.5% Notes. The holders of the 6.5% Notes have the right to
require the Company to purchase the 6.5% Notes for cash, including unpaid interest, on December&nbsp;15, 2010. The holders of the 6.5% Notes also have the right to require the Company to purchase the 6.5% Notes for cash upon the occurrence of a
fundamental change, as defined in the Indenture. In addition to the amounts described above, the Company will be required to pay a &#147;make-whole premium&#148; to the holders of the 6.5% Notes who elect to convert their notes into the
Company&#146;s common stock in connection with the fundamental change. The make-whole premium is payable in addition to shares of common stock and is calculated based on a formula with the premium ranging from 0 percent to 31.4 percent depending on
when the fundamental change occurs and the price of the Company&#146;s stock at the time the fundamental change occurs. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Upon conversion of
the 6.5% Notes, the Company has the right to deliver, in lieu of shares of its common stock, cash or a combination of cash and shares of its common stock. Under the indenture, the Company is required to notify holders of the 6.5% Notes of its method
for settling the principal amount of the 6.5% Notes upon conversion. This notification, once provided, is irrevocable and legally binding upon the Company with regard to any conversion of the 6.5% Notes. On March&nbsp;21, 2006, the Company notified
holders of the 6.5% Notes of its election to satisfy its conversion obligation with respect to the principal amount of any 6.5% Notes surrendered for conversion by paying the holders of such surrendered 6.5% Notes 100 percent of the principal
conversion obligation in the form of common stock of the Company. Until the 6.5% Notes are surrendered for conversion, the Company will not be required to notify holders of its method for settling the excess amount of the conversion obligation
relating to the amount of the conversion value above the principal amount, if any. In the event of a default of $10,000 or more on any credit agreement, including the 2004 Credit Facility and the 2.75% Notes, a corresponding event of default would
result under the 6.5% Notes. Unamortized debt issuance costs of $4,103 and $698 associated with the 6.5% Notes are included in other assets at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively, and are being amortized over the seven-year period ending
December 2012. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I>2.75% Convertible Senior Notes </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On March&nbsp;12, 2004, the Company completed a primary offering of $60,000 of 2.75% Convertible Senior Notes (the &#147;2.75% Notes&#148;). On April&nbsp;13, 2004, the initial purchasers of the 2.75% Notes exercised
their option to purchase an additional $10,000 aggregate principal amount of the notes. Collectively, the primary offering and purchase option of the 2.75% Notes totaled $70,000. The 2.75% Notes are general senior unsecured obligations. Interest is
paid semi-annually on March&nbsp;15 and September&nbsp;15 and payments began on September&nbsp;15, 2004. The 2.75% Notes mature on March&nbsp;15, 2024 unless the notes are repurchased, redeemed or converted earlier. The Company may redeem the 2.75%
Notes for cash on or after March&nbsp;15, 2011, at 100 percent of the principal amount of the notes plus accrued interest. The holders of the 2.75% Notes have the right to require the Company to purchase the 2.75% Notes, including unpaid interest,
on March&nbsp;15, 2011, 2014, and 2019 or upon a change of control related event. On March&nbsp;15, 2011 or upon a change in control event, the Company must pay the purchase price in cash. On March&nbsp;15, 2014 and 2019, the Company has the option
of providing its common stock in lieu of cash or a combination of common stock and cash to fund purchases. The holders of the 2.75% Notes may, under </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">81 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

<h5 align="left"><a href="#INDEX">Index to Financial Statements</a></h5>


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>WILLBROS GROUP, INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(In thousands,
except share and per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>7. Long-term Debt (continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">certain circumstances, convert the notes into shares of the Company&#146;s common stock at an initial conversion ratio of 51.3611 shares of common stock per
$1,000.00 principal amount of notes (representing a conversion price of approximately $19.47 per share resulting in 3,595,277 shares at December&nbsp;31, 2006 subject to adjustment in certain circumstances). The notes will be convertible only upon
the occurrence of certain specified events including, but not limited to, if, at certain times, the closing sale price of the Company&#146;s common stock exceeds 120 percent of the then current conversion price, or $23.36 per share, based on the
initial conversion price. In the event of a default under any Company credit agreement other than the indenture covering the 2.75% Notes, (1)&nbsp;in which the Company fails to pay principal or interest on indebtedness with an aggregate principal
balance of $10,000 or more; or (2)&nbsp;in which indebtedness with a principal balance of $10,000 or more is accelerated, an event of default would result under the 2.75% Notes. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On June&nbsp;10, 2005, the Company received a letter from a law firm representing an investor claiming to be the owner of in excess of 25 percent of the
2.75% Notes asserting that, as a result of the Company&#146;s failure to timely file with the SEC its 2004 Form 10-K and its Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2005, it was placing the Company on notice of an event of
default under the indenture dated as of March&nbsp;12, 2004 between the Company, as issuer, and JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., as trustee (the &#147;Indenture&#148;), which governs the 2.75% Notes. The Company indicated that it did not believe that it
had failed to perform its obligations under the relevant provisions of the Indenture referenced in the letter. On August&nbsp;19, 2005, the Company entered into a settlement agreement with the beneficial owner of the 2.75% Notes on behalf of whom
the notice of default was sent, pursuant to which the Company agreed to use commercially reasonable efforts to solicit the requisite vote to approve an amendment to the Indenture (the &#147;Indenture Amendment&#148;). The Company obtained the
requisite vote and on September&nbsp;22, 2005, the Indenture Amendment became effective. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Indenture Amendment extended the initial date
on or after which the 2.75% Notes may be redeemed by the Company to March&nbsp;15, 2013 from March&nbsp;15, 2011. In addition, a new provision was added to the Indenture which requires the Company, in the event of a &#147;fundamental change&#148;
which is a change of control event in which 10 percent or more of the consideration in the transaction consists of cash to make a coupon make-whole payment equal to the present value (discounted at the U.S. treasury rate) of the lesser of
(a)&nbsp;two years of scheduled payments of interest on the 2.75% Notes or (b)&nbsp;all scheduled interest on the 2.75% Notes from the date of the transaction through March&nbsp;15, 2013. Unamortized debt issue costs of $2,175 and $2,714 associated
with the 2.75% Notes are included in other assets at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively, and are being amortized over the seven-year period ending March 2011. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>2004 Credit Facility </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On March&nbsp;12, 2004, the existing $125,000 June 2002 credit agreement was
amended, restated and increased to $150,000 (the &#147;2004 Credit Facility&#148;). Although the 2004 Credit Facility was scheduled to mature on March&nbsp;12, 2007, it was replaced in October 2006 when the Company secured the 2006 Credit Facility
(see &#147;2006 Credit Facility&#148; above). The 2004 Credit Facility could be used for standby and commercial letters of credit, borrowings or a combination thereof. Borrowings were limited to the lesser of 40 percent of the borrowing base or
$30,000. Interest was payable quarterly at a base rate plus a margin ranging from 0.75 percent to 2.00 percent or on a Eurodollar rate plus a margin ranging from 1.75 percent to 3.00 percent. The 2004 Credit Facility was collateralized by
substantially all of the Company&#146;s assets, including stock of the Company&#146;s principal subsidiaries, prohibited the payment of cash dividends and required the Company to maintain certain financial ratios. The borrowing base was calculated
using varying percentages of cash, accounts receivable, accrued revenue, contract cost and recognized </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">82 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

<h5 align="left"><a href="#INDEX">Index to Financial Statements</a></h5>


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>WILLBROS GROUP, INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(In thousands,
except share and per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>7. Long-term Debt (continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">income not yet billed, property, plant and equipment, and spare parts. Unamortized debt issue costs of $982 associated with the 2004 Credit Facility are
included in other assets at December&nbsp;31, 2005. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As of October&nbsp;27, 2006 the Company terminated the 2004 Credit Facility with no
borrowings outstanding and reissued the letters of credit outstanding under the 2006 Credit Facility. There were $54,928 of letters of credit outstanding as of December&nbsp;31, 2005. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>2004 Credit Facility Waivers </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In January 2005, the Company obtained a Consent and Waiver from its
syndicated bank group, covering a period through June&nbsp;29, 2005, waiving certain defaults and covenants which related to the filing of tax returns, the payment of taxes when due, tax liens and legal proceedings against the Company related to a
tax assessment in Bolivia. Additional Consent and Waivers were obtained from the syndicated bank group as of April&nbsp;8 and June&nbsp;13, 2005 with respect to these defaults and non-compliance with certain financial covenants as of June&nbsp;13,
2005. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On July&nbsp;19, 2005, the Company entered into a Second Amendment and Waiver Agreement (&#147;Waiver Amendment&#148;) of the 2004
Credit Facility with the bank group to obtain continuing waivers regarding its non-compliance with certain financial and non-financial covenants in the 2004 Credit Facility. Under the terms of the Waiver Amendment, the total credit availability
under the 2004 Credit Facility was reduced to $100,000 as of the effective date of the Waiver Amendment. Subject to certain conditions, the bank group agreed to permanently waive all existing and probable technical defaults under the 2004 Credit
Facility as long as the Company submitted year-end 2004 financial statements and interim financial statements for the quarters ended March&nbsp;31 and June&nbsp;30, 2005 by September&nbsp;30, 2005. These conditions relate primarily to submissions of
various financial statements and other financial and borrowing base related information. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Waiver Amendment also modified certain of the
ongoing financial covenants under the 2004 Credit Facility and established a requirement that the Company maintain a minimum cash balance of $15,000. Until such time as the waiver became permanent, the Company had certain additional reporting
requirements, including periodic cash balance reporting. In addition, the Waiver Amendment prohibited the Company from borrowing cash under the 2004 Credit Facility until the waiver became permanent. The Company was not able to submit the referenced
statements by September&nbsp;30, 2005; therefore, the waiver did not become permanent. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">During the period from November&nbsp;23, 2005 to
June&nbsp;14, 2006, the Company entered into four additional amendments and waivers to the 2004 Credit Facility with its syndicated bank group to waive non-compliance with certain financial and non-financial covenants. Among other things, the
amendments provided that (1)&nbsp;certain financial covenants and reporting obligations were waived and/or modified to reflect the Company&#146;s current and anticipated future operating performance, (2)&nbsp;the ultimate reduction of the facility
to $70,000 for issuance of letter of credit obligations only, and (3)&nbsp;a requirement for the Company to maintain a minimum cash balance of $15,000. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On August&nbsp;18, 2006 the Company entered into a Sixth Amendment and Temporary Waiver Agreement (the &#147;Sixth Amendment&#148;) which waived the Company&#146;s failure to comply with certain financial covenants of
the 2004 Credit Facility during the fiscal quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 until the earlier of (i)&nbsp;September&nbsp;30, 2006 or (ii)&nbsp;the occurrence of a &#147;waiver default,&#148; which is a breach by the Company of any covenant, a
material breach of any representation and warranty or the occurrence of any default or event of default under the 2004 Credit Facility, other than the defaults which were temporarily waived by the Sixth Amendment. The Sixth Amendment </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">83 </FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>7. Long-term Debt (continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">further amended the 2004 Credit Facility to reduce the total commitment to $50,000 and provided for a letter of credit limit of $50,000 less the face amount
of letters of credit issued prior to August&nbsp;18, 2006, and provided that each new letter of credit must be fully cash collateralized and that a letter of credit fee of 0.25 percent be paid for each cash collateralized letter of credit. The Sixth
Amendment expired on September&nbsp;30, 2006, and availability under the 2004 Credit Facility was reduced to zero. On October&nbsp;27, 2006, the Company entered into a new $100,000 synthetic credit facility and reissued under this facility all the
then outstanding letters of credit (see &#147;2006 Credit Facility&#148; above). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Capital Leases </B></FONT></P> <P

</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Other Obligations </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company has various notes payable, generally related to equipment financing, and local revolving credit facilities. All are at market interest rates, and are collateralized by certain vehicles, equipment and/or
real estate. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

<h5 align="left"><a href="#INDEX">Index to Financial Statements</a></h5>


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>WILLBROS GROUP, INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(In thousands,
except share and per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>7. Long-term Debt (continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company has unsecured credit facilities with banks in certain countries outside the United
States. Borrowings in the form of short-term notes and overdrafts are made at competitive local interest rates. Generally, each line is available only for borrowings related to operations in a specific country. Credit available under these
facilities is approximately $4,582 at December&nbsp;31, 2006. There were no outstanding borrowings made under these facilities at December&nbsp;31, 2006 or 2005. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B>8. Retirement Benefits </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company has defined contribution plans that are funded by participating employee contributions
and the Company. The Company matches employee contributions, up to a maximum of four percent of salary, in the form of cash. All contributions in the form of WGI common stock were suspended in 2005, and removed as an option on January&nbsp;9, 2006.
Company contributions for the plans were $1,761, $1,909, and $1,423 (including WGI common stock valued at $0, $80 and $221) in 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B>9. Income Taxes </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The tax regimes of the countries in which the Company operates affect the consolidated income tax provision
of the Company and its effective tax rate. The effective consolidated tax rate differs from the United States (&#147;U.S.&#148;) federal statutory rate as tax rates and methods of determining taxes payable are different in each country. Moreover,
losses from one country generally cannot be used to offset taxable income from another country and, in some cases, certain expenses are not deductible for tax purposes. Income (loss) before income taxes and the provision (benefit) for income taxes
in the consolidated statements of operations consist of: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="92%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>WILLBROS GROUP, INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(In thousands,
except share and per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>9. Income Taxes (continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The provision for income taxes has been determined based upon the tax laws and rates in the countries
in which operations are conducted and income is earned. The Company and many of its subsidiaries are Panamanian companies. Panamanian tax law is based on territorial principles and does not impose income tax on income earned outside of Panama.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company&#146;s principal international operations are in Oman. The Company&#146;s subsidiary in Oman is subject to a corporate income
tax rate of 12 percent. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In 2004, the Company had foreign earnings which were non-taxable due to exemptions or tax holidays in certain
countries. Non-taxable foreign earnings for taxable year 2004 were $5,066. The Company did not have any non-taxable foreign earnings for taxable years 2005 and 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company&#146;s subsidiaries operating in the United States are subject to federal income tax rates up to 35 percent and varying state income tax rates and methods of computing tax liabilities. For 2006, the
Company&#146;s subsidiaries operating in Canada are subject to a federal income tax rate of 22.12 percent and a provincial income tax of 10.37 percent. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A reconciliation of the differences between the provision for income tax computed at the appropriate statutory rates and the reported provision for income taxes is as follows: </FONT></P> <P

</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company has total net tax assets equal to $6,173. The Company is owed tax refunds of $3,436,
which have been included in the Company&#146;s prepaid expenses. These refunds were primarily the result of the Company&#146;s ability to carry a significant portion of losses recognized in 2004 back to 2002 in order to offset taxable income
recognized in that year. For 2006, the Company owes various federal and state/provincial tax authorities $1,669, and this amount is included in accrued income taxes. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<h5 align="left"><a href="#INDEX">Index to Financial Statements</a></h5>


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>WILLBROS GROUP, INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(In thousands,
except share and per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>9. Income Taxes (continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TD>&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The ultimate realization of deferred tax assets related to net operating loss carry forwards
(including state net operating loss carry forwards) is dependent upon the generation of future taxable income in a particular tax jurisdiction during the periods in which the use of such net operating losses are allowed. Management considers the
scheduled reversal of deferred tax liabilities and projected future taxable income in making this assessment. In 2006, the Company utilized United States and Canada federal net operating losses of $14,854 and utilized state/provincial net operating
losses of $4,236. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company has remaining U.S. net operating loss carry forwards of $6,741 and state net
operating loss carry forwards of $7,769. The Company&#146;s federal net operating losses expire in 2013. A state net operating loss generally expires after five years in which the net operating loss was incurred. Based </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">87 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

<h5 align="left"><a href="#INDEX">Index to Financial Statements</a></h5>


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>WILLBROS GROUP, INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(In thousands,
except share and per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>9. Income Taxes (continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">upon the level of historical taxable income and projections for future taxable income over the periods in which the net operating losses can be utilized to
offset taxable income, management believes that the Company will realize the tax benefits of $2,564 from these loss carry forwards. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We
note that the Company&#146;s U.S. subsidiaries report taxable income on a consolidated tax return, which includes income from discontinued operations. The net operating losses of the consolidated group are shared by each subsidiary in the
consolidated group, including the Willbros Mt. West subsidiary in which a portion of its operations were discontinued. The table of deferred tax assets set forth above for 2005 reflected only a portion of the federal net operating loss that could
have been used by the Company&#146;s U.S. subsidiaries continuing operations. Net operating losses in the amount of $10,269 for 2005 were allocated to discontinued operations in order to offset any taxable gain derived from the sale of the Opal
TXP-4 gas production facility. However, based on the Company&#146;s tax position, the net operating losses previously allocated to discontinued operations, were allocated instead to continuing operations, thereby increasing the Company&#146;s net
operating loss deferred tax asset. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company also has net operating loss carry forwards derived in the United Kingdom, Bolivia, and
Pakistan of $43,154 as set forth below. The tax benefit from these net operating losses has been fully reserved and the total valuation allowance at December&nbsp;31, 2006 is $43,154. The Company also has written off previously recorded tax assets
fully reserved for because the Company does not have work planned in those countries in the future, there is no risk of a future taxable event, and/or net operating loss carry forwards have expired. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>10. Stockholders&#146; Equity </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I>Private Sale of Equity </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On October&nbsp;27, 2006, the Company completed a private placement of
equity to certain accredited investors pursuant to which the Company issued and sold 3,722,360 shares of the Company&#146;s common stock resulting in net proceeds of $48,748. The selling price was $14.00 per share which was a discount of
approximately 10 percent based on the Company&#146;s closing stock price of $15.50 on October&nbsp;24, 2006. Net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes primarily to support the start up of several new projects in the United States and
Canada. In conjunction with the private placement the Company also issued warrants to purchase an additional 558,354 shares of the Company&#146;s common stock. Each warrant is exercisable, in whole or in part, until 60 months from the date of
issuance. A warrant holder may elect to exercise the warrant&nbsp;by delivery of payment to the Company at the exercise price of $19.03 per share, or pursuant to a cashless exercise as provided in the warrant agreement. The fair value of the
warrants was $3,423 on the date of the grant, as calculated using the Black-Scholes option pricing model. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, all warrants to purchase common stock remained outstanding. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I>Stockholder Rights Plan </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On April&nbsp;1,
1999, the Company adopted a Stockholder Rights Plan and declared a distribution of one Preferred Share Purchase Right (&#147;Right&#148;) on each outstanding share of the Company&#146;s common stock. The </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">88 </FONT></P>

<h5 align="left"><a href="#INDEX">Index to Financial Statements</a></h5>


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>WILLBROS GROUP, INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(In thousands,
except share and per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>10. Stockholders&#146; Equity (continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">distribution was made on April&nbsp;15, 1999 to stockholders of record on that date. The Rights expire on April&nbsp;14, 2009. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Rights are exercisable only if a person or group acquires 15 percent or more of the Company&#146;s common stock or announces a tender offer the
consummation of which would result in ownership by a person or group of 15 percent or more of the common stock. Each Right entitles stockholders to buy one one-thousandth of a share of a series of junior participating preferred stock at an exercise
price of $30.00 per share. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If the Company is acquired in a merger or other business combination transaction after a person or group has
acquired 15 percent or more of the Company&#146;s outstanding common stock, each Right entitles its holder to purchase, at the Right&#146;s then-current exercise price, a number of acquiring company&#146;s common shares having a market value of
twice such price. In addition, if a person or group acquires 15 percent or more of the Company&#146;s outstanding common stock, each Right entitles its holder (other than such person or members of such group) to purchase, at the Right&#146;s
then-current exercise price, a number of the Company&#146;s common shares having a market value of twice such price. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Prior to the
acquisition by a person or group of beneficial ownership of 15 percent or more of the Company&#146;s common stock, the Rights are redeemable for one-half cent per Right at the option of the Company&#146;s Board of Directors. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I>Stock Ownership Plans </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The information
contained in this note pertains to continuing and discontinued operations. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">During May 1996, the Company established the Willbros Group,
Inc. 1996 Stock Plan (the &#147;1996 Plan&#148;) with 1,125,000 shares of common stock authorized for issuance to provide for awards to key employees of the Company, and the Willbros Group, Inc. Director Stock Plan (the &#147;Director Plan&#148;)
with 125,000 shares of common stock authorized for issuance to provide for the grant of stock options to non-employee directors. The number of shares authorized for issuance under the 1996 Plan, and the Director Plan, was increased to 4,075,000 and
225,000, respectively, by stockholder approval. The Director Plan expired August&nbsp;14, 2006, In 2006, the Company established the 2006 Director Restricted Stock Plan (the 2006 Director Plan) with 50,000 shares authorized for issuance to grant
shares of restricted stock to non-employee directors. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Restricted stock and restricted stock rights, also described collectively as
restricted stock units (&#147;RSU&#146;s&#148;), and options granted under the 1996 Plan vest generally over a three to four year period. Options granted under the Director Plan vest six months after the date of grant. Restricted stock granted under
the 2006 Director Plan vests one year after the date of grant. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the 1996 Plan had 791,236 shares and the 2006 Director Plan had 46,884 shares available for grant. There are an additional 356,000 shares in the 2006 Stock
Plan reserved for future grants required under employment agreements. Certain provisions allow for accelerated vesting based on increases of share prices and on eligible retirement. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, $3,247 of
compensation expense was recognized due to accelerated vesting of RSU&#146;s due to retirements and separation from the Company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Effective
January&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company adopted the fair value recognition provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;123R using the modified prospective application method. Under this method, compensation cost recognized during the </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">89 </FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>WILLBROS GROUP, INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(In thousands,
except share and per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>10. Stockholders&#146; Equity (continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 includes the applicable amounts of: (a)&nbsp;compensation expense of all share-based payments granted prior to, but not yet
vested as of, January&nbsp;1, 2006 (based on the grant-date fair value estimated in accordance with the original provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;123, and previously presented in the pro forma footnote disclosures in the Company&#146;s SEC reports), and
(b)&nbsp;compensation cost for all share-based payments granted subsequent to January&nbsp;1, 2006 (based on the grant-date fair value estimated in accordance with the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;123R). The Company uses the Black-Scholes valuation
method to determine the fair value of stock options granted as of the grant date. Results for prior periods have not been adjusted. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As a
result of adopting SFAS No.&nbsp;123R, the loss from continuing operations before income taxes and the net loss for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006&nbsp;both increased by $518 due to the additional compensation expense recorded. For the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, basic and diluted earnings per share were both negatively impacted by $.02 due to the implementation of SFAS No.&nbsp;123R. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Share-based compensation related to RSU&#146;s is recorded based on the Company&#146;s stock price as of the grant date. Recognition of share-based compensation related to RSU&#146;s was not impacted by the adoption
of SFAS No.&nbsp;123R. Expense from both stock options and RSU&#146;s totaled $7,240, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. The Company had no tax benefits related to either stock options or RSU&#146;s during the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Prior to January&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company accounted for awards granted under the stock ownership plans following the recognition
and measurement principles of Accounting Principles Board Opinion 25, &#147;Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees,&#148; and related Interpretations, as permitted by SFAS No.&nbsp;123. Because it is the Company&#146;s policy to grant stock
options at the market price on the date of grant, the intrinsic value of these grants was zero and, therefore, no compensation expense was recorded. Under the modified prospective application method, results for prior periods have not been adjusted
to reflect the effects of implementing SFAS No.&nbsp;123R. The following pro forma information is presented for comparative purposes and illustrates the pro forma effect on net loss and net loss per share as if the Company had applied the fair value
recognition provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;123 to share-based compensation prior to January&nbsp;1, 2006: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(In thousands,
except share and per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Volatility is calculated using an analysis of historical volatility. The Company believes that the
historical volatility of the Company&#146;s stock is the best method for estimating future volatility. The expected lives of options are determined based on the Company&#146;s historical share option exercise experience. The Company believes the
historical experience method is the best estimate of future exercise patterns currently available. The risk-free interest rates are determined using the implied yield currently available for zero-coupon U.S. government issues with a remaining term
equal to the expected life of the options. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company&#146;s stock option activity and related information consist of: </FONT></P> <P

options exercisable was $4,450 and $4,106, respectively. The weighted average remaining contractual term of outstanding options is 6.00 years and the weighted average remaining contractual term of the exercisable options is 4.84 years at
December&nbsp;31, 2006. The total intrinsic value of options exercised was $2,639, $298 and $3,689 during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004 respectively. There was no tax benefit realized related to those exercises. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The total fair value of options vested during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005, and 2004 was $357, $829 and $1,059, respectively.

<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The RSU&#146;s outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2006 include 225,000 RSU&#146;s which are vested
but have a deferred share issuance date. The total fair value of RSU&#146;s vested during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 was $6,990 and $1,583 respectively. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, there was a total of $4,151 of unrecognized compensation cost, net of estimated forfeitures, related to all non-vested
share-based compensation arrangements granted under the Company&#146;s stock ownership plans. That cost is expected to be recognized over a weighted-average period of 1.64 years. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In March 2002, certain officers of the Company borrowed a total of $1,307 under the Employee Stock Purchase Program, which permitted selected executives
and officers (exclusive of the Chief Executive Officer) to borrow from the Company up to 100 percent of the funds required to exercise vested stock options. The loans are full recourse, non-interest bearing for a period of up to five years and are
collateralized by the related stock. The difference of $434 between the discounted value of the loans and the fair market value of the stock on the date of exercise, and $119 representing the difference between the exercise price of certain options
and the fair market value of the stock was recorded as compensation expense at the date of exercise. The notes were recorded at the discounted value, and the discount was amortized as interest income over the periods the notes were outstanding. The
net loans receivable are presented as a reduction of stockholders&#146; equity. The maximum loan amount any one officer may have outstanding under the Employee Stock Purchase Program is $250. In accordance with The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, the
Company no longer makes loans to executive officers of the Company. All loans were settled in 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">92 </FONT></P>

</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In accordance with Emerging Issues Task Force (&#147;EITF&#148;) Issue 04-8, &#147;The Effect of
Contingently Convertible Instruments on Diluted Earnings per Share,&#148; the 8,408,448 shares issuable upon conversion of the convertible notes will be included in diluted income (loss) per share if those securities are dilutive, regardless of
whether the market trigger prices of $19.47 and $17.56, respectively, have been met. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>12. Segment Information </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company&#146;s segments are strategic business units that are managed separately as each has different operational requirements and marketing
strategies. Because of the composition of work and the nuances of the geographic markets the Company serves, the Company has managed and reported operating results on a geographic basis consisting of two operating segments: <I>United
States&nbsp;&amp; Canada</I> and <I>International</I>. The <I>International</I> segment consists of all construction, engineering and facilities development operations in countries other than the United States and Canada. Currently such operations
are primarily in the Middle East. The <I>United States&nbsp;&amp; Canada</I> segment consists of all construction, engineering and facilities development operations in the </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">93 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

<h5 align="left"><a href="#INDEX">Index to Financial Statements</a></h5>


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>WILLBROS GROUP, INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(In thousands,
except share and per share amounts) </B></FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>12. Segment Information (continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">United States and Canada. The Company&#146;s corporate operations include the general and administrative and financing functions of the organization. The
costs of these functions are allocated between the two operating segments. The Company&#146;s corporate operations also include various other assets that are allocated between the two operating segments. Inter-segment revenue and revenue between
geographic areas are not material. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The tables below reflect the Company&#146;s business segments as of and for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005, and 2004: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
